title: Paper Porcelain Espresso Cup, Prototype, 2009
medium: slip cast, fired unglazed porcelain with added metal drill dust, applied pencil lines, applied marker or ink
markings: "S&B / 2009 / 2" applied to underside in marker or ink
provenance: 2014, acquired by Cooper-Hewitt directly from the designers.
dimensions: H x W x D: 6 x 7.6 x 5.1 cm (2 3/8 in. x 3 in. x 2 in.)
creditline: Museum purchase from General Acquisitions Endowment Fund
description: Slip cast cylindrical cup with straight sides, squared D-shaped tab handle and curved tapered base. Light gray unglazed porcelain with regularly-spaced, narrow vertical scores terminating at a horizontal score towards base; broader vertical scores at curved base, all with applied pencil. "S&B / 2009 / 2" mark applied to underside in marker or ink
label_text: The Paper Porcelain tableware series was conceived as a project to translate paper models—an integral part of the designer’s process—into porcelain. Dutch designers Stefan Scholten (b. 1972) and Carole Baijings (b. 1973) started by drawing to figure out forms, geometry, and color. Next, they created cut, folded, scored, and taped cardboard models, and then unglazed porcelain prototypes. To recreate the cardboard’s spotted, gray surface in the porcelain prototypes, the designers developed a specific mix of porcelain to which they added metal drill dust. Strips of paper tape on the cardboard models were recreated using ceramic glazes. Pencil lines applied by hand to the porcelain prototypes indicated the scored lines of the cardboard. The final tableware manufactured by Hay is made of molded and glazed porcelain, and faithfully mimics the spotted gray of the original cardboard and the beige “paper tape.”

tombstone.epitaph: Paper Porcelain Espresso Cup, Prototype, 2009. slip cast, fired unglazed porcelain with added metal drill dust, applied pencil lines, applied marker or ink. Museum purchase from General Acquisitions Endowment Fund. 2014-38-3.
